title: 107_hr2102
content: The "Rural Teachers Recruitment Act of 2001" is also known as the Teacher Recruitment and Retention Grants Act. The Secretary is authorized to provide grants to rural eligible local educational agencies to recruit and retain qualified teachers for elementary and secondary schools. Eligible agencies must demonstrate a need for additional teachers and grants will be of sufficient size to develop incentive programs. A rural eligible local educational agency receiving a grant can use funds for incentive programs to recruit and retain qualified teachers, including salary increases, certification expenses reimbursement, college tuition assistance, graduate school tuition support, and relocation expense reimbursement. Definitions for "local educational agency" and "metropolitan statistical area" are provided. The term "rural eligible educational agency" refers to a local educational agency located outside a metropolitan statistical area with at least 20% of children from families below the poverty level. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. Authorization of appropriations includes $250 million for each of fiscal years 2002 and 2003, $400 million for each of fiscal years 2004 and 2005, and $500 million for fiscal year 2006. Loan forgiveness for rural teachers is amended under the Higher Education Act of 1965. Teachers can qualify for loan cancellation by teaching in a school for 5 consecutive years or in a county with a low population density for 3 consecutive years. SEC. 2104 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 amends Part A of title II to provide professional development in mathematics and science for rural teachers. The Secretary may award grants to rural eligible local educational agencies for professional development programs in mathematics and science for teachers. To be eligible, agencies must submit an application containing required information. Definitions include 'metropolitan statistical area' and 'rural eligible local educational agency'. The Secretary may award grants to rural eligible local educational agencies for professional development programs in mathematics and science for teachers. Eligibility criteria include serving children from families below the poverty level.
